title: Why does smoke follow you around a fire?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of smoke blowing back into your face when you move away from a fire?

options.label: A
options.text: The air around you is affected by the fire

options.label: B
options.text: You create a vacuum that pulls smoke towards you

options.label: C
options.text: The fire itself releases smoke that follows you

options.label: D
options.text: External wind blows the smoke in your direction

multiple-choice.question: What happens to air molecules near a fire as they absorb heat from the fire?

options.label: A
options.text: They slow down and become less dense

options.label: B
options.text: They speed up and become more dense

options.label: C
options.text: They remain at rest

options.label: D
options.text: They change phase from gas to liquid

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why dense air sinks, rather than rising?

options.label: B
options.text: Because gravity pulls it down more than the air pushes it up

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's colder than the air around it

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has a higher pressure than the air above it

multiple-choice.question: What is convection, and how does it relate to the movement of hot air near a fire?

options.label: A
options.text: Convection is the process by which cold air rises; it's relevant to the movement of hot air away from a fire.

options.label: B
options.text: Convection is the process by which hot air rises because it weighs less than the air around it.

options.label: C
options.text: Convection is the process by which heat energy is transferred through the movement of fluids (gases or liquids); in this context, it's relevant to the movement of hot air near a fire.

options.label: D
options.text: Convection is not relevant to the movement of hot air near a fire; it's only related to the movement of cold air.

title: How to deal with rejection
